title: Endpoint regularity of general Fourier integral operators
abstract:
Let $n\geq 1,0<\rho<1, \max\{\rho,1-\rho\}\leq \delta\leq 1$ and
$$m_1=\rho-n+(n-1)\min\{\frac 12,\rho\}+\frac {1-\delta}{2}.$$ If the amplitude
$a$ belongs to the H\"{o}rmander class $S^{m_1}_{\rho,\delta}$ and $\phi\in
\Phi^{2}$ satisfies the strong non-degeneracy condition, then we prove that the
following Fourier integral operator $T_{\phi,a}$ defined by \begin{align*}
T_{\phi,a}f(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}e^{i\phi(x,\xi)}a(x,\xi)\widehat{f}(\xi)d\xi,
\end{align*} is bounded from the local Hardy space $h^1(\mathbb{R}^n)$ to
$L^1(\mathbb{R}^n)$. As a corollary, we can also obtain the corresponding
$L^p(\mathbb{R}^n)$-boundedness when $1<p<2$.
  These theorems are rigorous improvements on the recent works of Staubach and
his collaborators. When $0\leq \rho\leq 1,\delta\leq \max\{\rho,1-\rho\}$, by
using some similar techniques in this note, we can get the corresponding
theorems which coincide with the known results.
